> Please excuse my ignorance, but isn't there resource settings for log4j which we can work with.

Yeah there is a way to configure the log level for particular package/class in `log4j2.properties`. However, there is no way to configure the log level for a particular test as the setting is applicable for all the tests within the module and enabling `INFO` level for `helix-core` tests is expensive as the log size grew to ~2.5GB. So, unfortunately programatically changing the log level is the only way out.

This change is approved by @desaikomal

I was got a wrong impression on the these throttler will be in intermediateStage for throttling.

If it is only used in WAGED, I would suggest to name it "Filter" instead of throttler. Because there is already a state transition throttler in intermediateStage.

Commit message:  let us use exponential back-off when request fails on ZK side.

Could you please elaborate why the Set does not work? We are using set because of we do observe the list operation can cause a huge delay in computation for other scenarios.

Unless we have a strong reason using List or clear drawback for Set, I prefer to keep the set.
This test fails in: https://github.com/apache/helix/actions/runs/4887998002

I had tried this when WAGED is firstly developed. What I can tell is that performance will be terrible and the rebalancer basically unusable in middle to large size clusters.

And to be complete, I also tried to add a hashcode then using a map with item counts as value. I remember the speed is better, but not good enough for production usage.

Do we have any logic fails that makes you believe we should add hashcode back? I mean what's the real problem?

Actually, if you really want to make things straight, I would suggest changing the equal method, so different objects won't be equal and we can add another method just to compare replica's ID. But I forgot if any library code calls equal inside so we won't be able to promote the new equal method... Just my two cents.

Overall performance is one of the most important things for the rebalancer and we cannot compromise.
This is an interesting problem. Is it possible for you to write up an one-pager to elaborate your proposal? I feel we'd better not rush to coding before the high level direction is clear.
This test fails in: https://github.com/apache/helix/actions/runs/4888566173

> Could you please elaborate why the Set does not work? We are using set because of we do observe the list operation can cause a huge delay in computation for other scenarios.
> 
> Unless we have a strong reason using List or clear drawback for Set, I prefer to keep the set.

@junkaixue 
Please refer to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2265503/why-do-i-need-to-override-the-equals-and-hashcode-methods-in-java, we are not using it right. Two "equaled" object will be hashed into different bucket (or with collision, same bucket). There is no point using set over list in our case if `hashCode` isn't overriden. 

Besides, arraylist has better performance than hashset in both time and memory, https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10799417/performance-and-memory-allocation-comparison-between-list-and-set

> I had tried this when WAGED is firstly developed. What I can tell is that performance will be terrible and the rebalancer basically unusable in middle to large size clusters.
> 
> And to be complete, I also tried to add a hashcode then using a map with item counts as value. I remember the speed is better, but not good enough for production usage.
> 
> Do we have any logic fails that makes you believe we should add hashcode back? I mean what's the real problem?

@jiajunwang 
I don't quite understand the performance part. First, we are not using contains logic, so basically it's plain container or collection for either list or set. Second, a simple benchmarking test shows list has better performance in both time and memory, similar as in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10799417/performance-and-memory-allocation-comparison-between-list-and-set

The most fundamental problem is this class is violating the contract of Object.hashCode, it confuses people as two equaled objects can have different hashcode, what's worse, as in the description, it doesn't work well with hash-based collections. There is no direct logic breaking. This is a cleanup and performance boost.

@jiajunwang - can you please elaborate on performance concern? From correctness point of view, @qqu0127 seems to be correct? we will have same kind of objects hashed differently.  We have 2 things here:
(a) Adding 'hashCode' 
(b) choosing List over Set.

I think (a) is required for correctness. (b) is for performance based on what Quincy has pointed out. Are we in disagreement on (a) or (b) ?
@jiajunwang - can you please help review, i have addressed your comment and reverted to using String.format().

> I was got a wrong impression on the these throttler will be in intermediateStage for throttling.
> 
> If it is only used in WAGED, I would suggest to name it "Filter" instead of throttler. Because there is already a state transition throttler in intermediateStage.

This will be applied to intermediateStage. It is NOT reserved for WAGED, it can apply to any rebalancer. Because the state transition is in planning phase (how we schedule movement), which is after the idealstate is calculated.
In my opinion, this will be merged with the state transition throttler eventually
@jiajunwang Please refer to https://github.com/apache/helix/wiki/WAGED-rebalancer-Hard-Constraint-Scope-Expansion

This change has been approved by @jiajunwang , @qqu0127 
Commit message: simple change for consistency

> > I was got a wrong impression on the these throttler will be in intermediateStage for throttling.
> > If it is only used in WAGED, I would suggest to name it "Filter" instead of throttler. Because there is already a state transition throttler in intermediateStage.
> 
> This will be applied to intermediateStage. It is NOT reserved for WAGED, it can apply to any rebalancer. Because the state transition is in planning phase (how we schedule movement), which is after the idealstate is calculated. In my opinion, this will be merged with the state transition throttler eventually

Ah... Then I would suggest not do this. The reason is that we followed similar pattern to solve the problem. For example, if it is delay caused wrong assignment, then let's resolve it in best possible. This is same story here. So we can keep each stage do its own work.

Also adding this hybrid (assignment and throttling) mode, can cause the more complexity in throttling and the debugging will be much much harder. Say if user would like to ask why the message has been throttled, previous logic is simple, we can clear tell it is throttled because of out of quota. But now, we need to go through same analysis for assignment and tell the reason of why the state transition is throttled.


@jiajunwang what do you think?

I had to download the code to remind myself what happened exactly...
Since we have added an index to cover searching functionality, I agree that it seems the Set here can be changed to List. I guess it was carried over from the performance enhancement attempts I tried as I mentioned earlier in this thread.

Given that saying, I think we should consider removing the equals() override instead of adding new hashcode override. At a high level, AssignableReplica objects are different event their resource/partition/state keys are the same. So I'm actually more concerned of adding hashCode which makes 2 different replica object identical.
I tried to search for all AssignableReplica usages to confirm that if equals is still needed. Seems OK to remove, but please double check : )
Also, please run some benchmark to ensure that we don't miss anything.

And this is a good catch. Thanks for the change!

@jiajunwang 
> So I'm actually more concerned of adding hashCode which makes 2 different replica object identical.

Adding hashCode won't make them identical, (well, in fact it's happening because `equals()`), having same hashCode doesn't necessarily mean the two objects are same, but two equaled objects must have same hash. Adding hashCode isn't making it worse or better, but make it consistent.

Also FYI, `equals()` is used in https://github.com/apache/helix/blob/master/helix-core/src/main/java/org/apache/helix/controller/rebalancer/waged/model/AssignableNode.java#L149
So, I'd prefer keeping `equals()` and adding `hashCode()`

> I had to download the code to remind myself what happened exactly... Since we have added an index to cover searching functionality, I agree that it seems the Set here can be changed to List. I guess it was carried over from the performance enhancement attempts I tried as I mentioned earlier in this thread.
> 
> Given that saying, I think we should consider removing the equals() override instead of adding new hashcode override. At a high level, AssignableReplica objects are different event their resource/partition/state keys are the same. So I'm actually more concerned of adding hashCode which makes 2 different replica object identical. I tried to search for all AssignableReplica usages to confirm that if equals is still needed. Seems OK to remove, but please double check : ) Also, please run some benchmark to ensure that we don't miss anything.
> 
> And this is a good catch. Thanks for the change!

I remember the old set better than list is when we have removeAll and contains operation :). If we have this kind of operation, the performance will be huge slow.

@junkaixue , @jiajunwang , @NealSun96 - can you please look at the design proposal and let us know your view?
I do like the separation of concern approach where BestPossibleAssignment does what is the right assignment and we have another stage which does the "filtering" / "throttlng" based on the current state. One stage is doing pure computation while other is trying to take us towards that ideal computed state and doing right "ordering". If you guys think, we need to introduce one additional stage in the pipeline can help, we can think about that too.
But let us close on this please.
thanks,

Commit message: Code cleanup

@qqu0127 thanks a lot for the writeup. I like the straightforward way the problems and proposals are elaborated. The github wiki is not easy for us to comment, if we are looking for more external comments, I would suggest creating a Google Doc first and then convert to wiki when the idea is converged. cc @desaikomal 

Given that saying, here're my thoughts:
1. Highlevel idea makes sense. And we should do it.
2. Kind of extending the topic a little bit.
If we believe the "capacity" of the node can precisely predict it's real capability of hosting workload, do we still need evenness? Does it make sense if we just add partitions to a node until the workload weight is about to exceed "capacity"? What I'm trying to say is that, if users are using this weight/capacity system more seriously, we shall consider simplify the design instead of adding more layers to it. The thing is that, although each design makes great sense, if we implement all of them in one system, the system becomes too complicated and unmanagible.
On the other hand, if the "capacity" is just rough estimate, is it worthy to precisely control the transient transitions and sacrifice converge speed?

I couldn't find a way to share Google doc from my official LinkedIn account. Here is the  write up in Google Doc: (komald@gmail.com/desaimom)

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uxCqSU0xriUTdZIyxVoEvPMvywRgHCANatUlR0YQojk/edit#

Please note: I have added a new proposal - Approach-2. 
@jiajunwang  @NealSun96 @qqu0127 @junkaixue  - Please review and get back to us soon as there are few consumers waiting for this fix. Thanks,
komal
